category.text: $course$/top/Default for qb/Gapfill English Language Questions/Irregular Verbs

generalfeedback.text: 'Are' is the plural form of the verb 'to be', but this is referring to something singular (you). Am is the first person form of the verb to be so Am is the correct selection.

hint.text: The first letter of the correct answer will be added to each incorrect gap when you press try again.
The next letter of the correct answer will be added when you press try again

questiontext.text: In the last race yesterday, he [beat] everyone and got first prize.
The ice cream was cold when I [bit] into it.
When I cut my thumb it [bled] so I put a bandage on it.
In the high wind the old tree was [blown] down.
My parents were young when they [bought] their house
How many people [came] to the concert?
Yesterday I used scissors to [cut] the photo out of the magazine
Last summer we sat on the beach and [drank] orange juice.
We searched until we [found] the missing photo.
It happened so long ago I have [forgotten] the details.
It was so cold that the water had [frozen]
The students [have] a new subject to study.
I [have] a blue on and my brother [has] a red one.
When he shouted your name he [meant] no harm.
Until last year my father [taught] French.
I was so excited I [ran] all the way home.
I [was] waiting for the kettle to boil
I played tennis with Paul last week and I [beat] him.
After going to the gym for three months I [became] stronger.
When I was at school I did not [know] how to play guitar.
Last Saturday I [drank] four cups of coffee

incorrectfeedback.text: Because it starts 'Last Saturday' the verb must be in the past tense.

questiontext.text: I saw John on Saturday and I [gave] him the keys.

incorrectfeedback.text: 'I saw John on Saturday' indicates this is in the past tense.

questiontext.text: When my mother walked to the car I [held] her hand.
When I was at the hotel I [kept] my in my suitcase.
Last Saturday I [left] the party at midnight
Last year I [ran] in the London marathon.
When his new book came out I [read] it as soon as I could.
I borrowed half the money from the bank and by summer I had [repaid] it all.
Last summer I [rode] my bicycle across northern England.
I looked out the window and [saw] the car arrive.
I [saw] an interesting TV program about London.
When we were at the zoo I  [saw] an elephant.
When I was on holiday I [slept] until 10 O'clock every day.
I met my wife when we [were] learning English
Last year I [took] my mother on holiday.
I could not sleep because the air conditioning was [making] a noise.

Type the end letter to form the Simple Past/Past Participle of the verb i

e.g. I shout, yesterday I shouted.

I bend, yesterday I [bent]

I spend, yesterday I [spent]

I walk, yesterday I [walked]

I lend, yesterday I [lent]
By the time I arrived the game had already [begun].

incorrectfeedback.text: It would be more common to say "the game had already started", but begun is also correct.

questiontext.text: The house [shook] every time a plane landed.
It was so cold that the water had [frozen].
The got a good price when they [sold] their house.
The machine was very loud and I could not hear what he [said].
On my birthday we were [driven] in a taxi to the restaurant.
We [were] waiting for the kettle to boil.
I remember the day when we first [met].
He had slept for 8 hours and was exited when he [woke] up.

category.text: $course$/top/Default for qb/Gapfill English Language Questions/Baby animals

questiontext.text: A new born dog is called a [puppy]
That video was not [as] good [as] the last one.
Is the ice cream [better] than the pie?
Taking the train is faster [than] going by bus.
This test is [more difficult than] the last one.
My new flat is bigger [than] the old one.
My new phone is similar [to] my old phone

category.text: $course$/top/Default for qb/Gapfill English Language Questions/Adjective order

partiallycorrectfeedback.text:
There is a general rule that adjectives should go in the the following order

Opinion,Size,Age,Shape,Colour,Material,Origin,Purpose

So in this case beautiful is an opinion, old is an age, and red is a color.

incorrectfeedback.text:
There is a general rule that adjectives should go in the the following order

Opinion,Size,Age,Shape,Colour,Material,Origin,Purpose

So in this case beautiful is an opinion, old is an age, and red is a color.

partiallycorrectfeedback.text:
There is a general rule that adjectives should go in the the following order

Opinion,Size,Age,Shape,Colour,Material,Origin,Purpose

So in this case beautiful is an opinion, old is an age, and red is a color.

incorrectfeedback.text:
There is a general rule that adjectives should go in the the following order

Opinion,Size,Age,Shape,Colour,Material,Origin,Purpose

So in this case beautiful is an opinion, old is an age, and red is a color. 

is incorrect.

There is a general rule that adjectives should go in the the following order

Opinion,Size,Age,Shape,Colour,Material,Origin,Purpose

So in this case brown is a color so comes before leather which is a material (what the shoes are made of)

partiallycorrectfeedback.text:
There is a general rule that adjectives should go in the the following order

Opinion,Size,Age,Shape,Colour,Material,Origin,Purpose

So in this case beautiful is an opinion, old is an age, and blue is a color and Chinese is the origin

There is a general rule that adjectives should go in the the following order

So in this case large is size, old is age and  wooden is material

Your answer is partially correct.

incorrectfeedback.text:
There is a general rule that adjectives should go in the the following order

Opinion,Size,Age,Shape,Colour,Material,Origin,Purpose

So in this case large is size, old is age and  wooden is material

Your answer is partially correct.

Your answer is incorrect.

There is a general rule that adjectives should go in the the following order

Opinion,Size,Age,Shape,Colour,Material,Origin,Purpose

So in this case incredibly is an opinion and fast is a (sort of) size.

There is a general rule that adjectives should go in the the following order

Opinion,Size,Age,Shape,Colour,Material,Origin,Purpose

So in this case lovely is an opinion and so comes before big

There is a general rule that adjectives should go in the the following order

Opinion,Size,Age,Shape,Colour,Material,Origin,Purpose

So in this case brown is a lovely is an opinion and so becomes before old.

questiontext.text:
Put the descriptive words in the correct order. 

She wore a  [beautiful] [long] [red] dress

generalfeedback.text:
The rule in English is that the order of adjectives (describing words) should be

  • Quantity or number
  • Quality or opinion
  • Size
  • Age
  • Shape
  • Color
  • Proper adjective (often nationality, other place of origin, or material)
  • Purpose or qualifier

incorrectfeedback.text:
According to this article in Wikipedia (retrieved 25/10/2016)
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Adjective#Adjective_order

In general, the adjective order in English is:

  1. Determiners articles, adverbs, and other limiters.
  2. Observation postdeterminers and limiter adjectives (e.g., a real hero, a perfect idiot) and adjectives subject to subjective measure (e.g., beautiful, interesting), or objects with a value (e.g., best, cheapest, costly)
  3. Size and shape adjectives subject to objective measure (e.g., wealthy, large, round), and physical properties such as speed.
  4. Age adjectives denoting age (e.g., young, old, new, ancient, six-year-old).
  5. Color adjectives denoting color (e.g., red, black, pale).
  6. Origin denominal adjectives denoting source of noun (e.g., French, American, Canadian).
  7. Material denominal adjectives denoting what something is made of (e.g., woolen, metallic, wooden).
  8. Qualifier final limiter, often regarded as part of the noun (e.g., rocking chair, hunting cabin, passenger car, book cover).

questiontext.text: Last night we watched a [wonderful old] movie.

incorrectfeedback.text:
There is a general rule that adjectives should go in the the following order

Opinion,Size,Age,Shape,Colour,Material,Origin,Purpose

So in this case wonderful is an opinion  so comes before old (age)

questiontext.text: I still have a large [amount] of work to do.
Poetry gives me a huge [amount] of pleasure

incorrectfeedback.text: Pleasure is not countable, you cannot say I have 5Kg of pleasure or 2 metres of pleasure so the word amount is used.

questiontext.text: I have a [number] of questions for you.
At Christmas we are all under a huge [amount] of stress
There is a [little] coffee left in the pot
If you give me a [few] pounds I will buy some fruit.
I added a [few] straberries to my breakfast cereal
If you are still hungry I have a [few] nuts left.
The exam is difficult and [few] people score 100%

incorrectfeedback.text: The word is not countable, if the question was about apples, which are individual items, the expression "How many apples did I eat" would be correct.
The word many is used where the item is countable, so pens are very countable. If the question was about water, sand it would be how much.

questiontext.text: Do you think [many] people will come to the party?
How [much] money have you got with you?
I prefer more action and [less] romance in movies.
[Many] people in the UK like to eat curry
There are not [many] apples left in the fruit bowl

incorrectfeedback.text: Much is used for situations where the item is not directly quantifiable, it would be grammatically correct to ask "how many litres of water in the sea", or how many apples are in the bowl. You could ask "how much money have you got", as money is not a quantity.

questiontext.text: Each box contained 10 tasty [apples]. We gave a box to each of the [children] to eat.
I am going to the shop to buy [a] cake
When you are at the shop, please buy [some] sugar.
At the party all the [children] wore a badge. I made sandwiches and used three [loaves] of bread. Two of the [women] who work at the bakers delivered cakes.
After the long walk he had sore [feet]
I saw several [geese] in the park
When they came home from school I chopped the Melon into [halves] and gave them to the [children]
I counted the adults, there were 10 [women|men] and 5 [men|women] at the meeting. We were there to discuss the [feet] of the 20 school [children] who had been at the park.
There were ten [men] working on the road.
On the farm we saw several [mice].
He had bought his new camera and showed me all of his [photos]
In the summer [people] row [boats] on the river.
By midnight the dance hall was full of [people]
The teacher went to the park with 12 [children] from her class.
I saw two old [men] in the barbers.
I use an electric tooth brush to clean my [teeth]
I took my son to the dentist where he had two [teeth] filled
The dentist had to remove two of his [teeth]
The married men bought their [wives] to the party.

incorrectfeedback.text:
Your answer is incorrect. This resource may help
.https://learnenglish.britishcouncil.org/english-grammar/adverbials-time

questiontext.text: I have not played tennis [for] many years.
I have been a student [for] two years.
I worked on the farm [for] two years.
I have been learning english [for] two years.
I have been working on this job [for] two days
I have been working on this job [since] Monday
I have been working here [for ten years].
I have been working on this project [since] January
I sent a text [while] I was waiting for the bus
I wrote an email [while] peter was washing up.
How [many] bottles of water did you bring?
How [many of] you would like ice cream?
[Many of] us were happy to be leaving.

incorrectfeedback.text: English has two articles, the and the words a/an. If you are referring to a specific banana you would say pass the banana. In this case you are interested in any banana so the article is either a or an. The reason it is an is because banana is a singular noun that starts with a consonant. If the fruit asked for began with a vowel (a,e,i,o or u) then the article word would be an, so if the fruit was an apple you would say "would you like an apple?"

English has two articles, the and the words a/an. If you are referring to a specific cup of tea you might  I stirred the tea. In this case you are interested in any cup of tea so the article is either a or an. The reason it is a is because cup is a singular noun that starts with a consonant. If the item offered asked for began with a vowel (a,e,i,o or u) then the article word would be an, so if item offered was ice cream you would say  "would you like an ice cream?"

questiontext.text: Can you give me [!!] advice about this?

incorrectfeedback.text: To score on this you needed to leave the gap blank.  Some words in English are considered 'uncountable' so require no article. Other examples are information, air, salt and fun

partiallycorrectfeedback.text: Your answer is partially correct, and the gap should be left blank.

incorrectfeedback.text: This is 'trick' question as none of the options are correct. There is no need for a word between have and fun.

questiontext.text: I would like to buy [a] house.

incorrectfeedback.text: It is correct to say the house, or a house. It is not correct to say an house because an is only used before a word starting with  a vowel (a,e,i,o,u). So you can say an apple, but not a apple.

hint.text: Incorrect, try again.

questiontext.text: I bought [a] new car last week.  I have been reading [an] excellent book about the company that make it.

gapsetting.incorrectfeedback: Because new does not start with a vowel, a must be used.

incorrectfeedback.text: Your answer is incorrect. Generally when you have a word that starts with a vowel (a,e,i,o,u) you would use an. If not then you can use a, e.g. I live in a house.

questiontext.text: We saw [!!] ducks in the park. I [lay] on the  grass in the sun for [an] hour.
Pass me [an] apple and pull [the] chair closer. Have you got [a] cusion?

To get full marks, one or more gaps must be left blank.

[!!] France is a member of the EU.

[The] French have a long history of making wine

[!!] French is spoken widely in Quebec

[The] French port of Marseilles is on the Mediterranean sea.

To get full marks you will need to leave one or more of these options empty.

The capital of the UK is [!!] London

I came from Scotland on [the] train

Moscow is [the] capital of Russia

I am going to [!!] Paris on the train.

correctfeedback.text: Your answer is correct. If something has a name (e.g. London or Paris) then it does not require the definite article "the" in front of it.

partiallycorrectfeedback.text: Your answer is partially correct. If something has a name (e.g. London or Paris) then it does not require the definite article "the" in front of it.

incorrectfeedback.text: Your answer is incorrect. If something has a name (e.g. London or Paris) then it does not require the definite article "the" in front of it.

questiontext.text: Who is [the|that] man in the big hat?

To get full marks, one or more gaps must be left blank.

[!!] William Shakespeare wrote plays 

[The] Amazon river is in south America 

[The] River Thames flows through London 

[!!] English is widely spoken in the Netherlands
Would you like [an] egg for breakfast, with toast [and] marmalade? I will make [the] coffee

category.text: $course$/top/Default for qb/Gapfill English Language Questions/Collective Nouns

questiontext.text: The farmer showed us his field where he had a [herd] of cows.
While swimming in the sea we saw a large [shoal] of fish.
A shepherd is someone that looks after a [flock] of sheep.
At the zoo they have a [pack] of wolves.

category.text: $course$/top/Default for qb/Gapfill English Language Questions/Auxilliary Verbs

incorrectfeedback.text: Use did with all forms of the past tense.
Use does when referring to he,she or it

questiontext.text: [He's] talking to his father on the phone.

incorrectfeedback.text: He's is a contraction of He is. It would be correct to write He is, but in spoken English the two words are normally pushed together to form He's.

questiontext.text: I [have] a good reason for being late.

incorrectfeedback.text: Use did with all forms of the past tense.

category.text: $course$/top/Default for qb/Gapfill English Language Questions/Gerunds and Infinitives

questiontext.text: I miss [working] with young people, I may ask for my old job back.
He agreed [to help] me finish the work.
They [have to] be here by 8 in the morning to catch the train.
You [have to] be here by 9 if you want to get in.
He [has to] bring his ticket if he wants to get in.
In the U.K. motorcyclists [have] to wear a helmet.
I [have to] leave now or I will miss the train.
I [have to] finish work at five today.

Form the words into a correct sentence.

[He] [speaks] [english] [well]

Identify the Subect, Verb and Object of this sentence 

My father[s] fixed[v] the car[o]
When you arrive [at] the station, walk [to] the hotel.
When you arrive [at] the station, walk [to] the hotel.

Prepositions are short words (on, in, to) that usually stand in front of nouns (sometimes also in front of gerund verbs).

Add the correct prepositions to the following text.

I will go to work [on] monday.

I hope to go to France [in] two months.

I have been studying English [for] three years

Prepositions are short words (on, in, to) that usually stand in front of nouns (sometimes also in front of gerund verbs).

Add the correct prepositions to the following text.

I will go to work [on] monday.

I hope to go to France [in] two months.

I have been studying English [for] three years
I walked [to] the station and got on the train. Five hours later I had reached [!!] my destination.

gapsetting.incorrectfeedback: Surprisingly, no preposition word is required in this situation

questiontext.text: I walked [to] the station and got on the train. Five hours later I had reached [!!] my destination.

gapsetting.incorrectfeedback: Surprisingly, no preposition word is required in this situation

questiontext.text: Some people are rich, some people are poor, life is not [fair]

incorrectfeedback.text: Your answer is incorrect, The word fare refers to the purchase price of something, typically on public transport, e.g. what is the fare to London, fayre refers to items of food but is rarely used in normal conversation. The word fair can also be used to referred to a public gathering, e.g. the county fair or an agricultural fair. http://www.dictionary.com/browse/fair

gapsetting.incorrectfeedback: The spelling flower means  plant that is grown for its blossoms, e.g. a rose.

The whole family wanted to have apple crumble for dessert.

When we get there [what] do you want to eat for lunch?
I cannot find the drill, [where] did you put it?
You should have been here an hour ago, [why] are you so late?

category.text: $course$/top/Default for qb/Gapfill English Language Questions/Subject verb agreement

incorrectfeedback.text: This is about subject and verb agreement. Because it is about me the subject is singular he and play is the singular. If it were multiple, e.g. with friends it would be "he plays football with his friends"

questiontext.text:
Arranged the words to make a sentence.

[I] [cycled] [to] [work]

incorrectfeedback.text: Because the subject I is singular was is used. If the subject was plural such as we, then it would be "We were asleep"
Because I is singlular it must be matched by the singular was. If it was a plural subect, for example we, then it would be we were waiting for you.

The house was built [passive]
Peter cooked the meal [active]
Someone fed the dog [passive]

questiontext.text:
[The battery is flat], do you have a charger?

[I need a pound coin], do you have any change?

[What is the weather like], will I need my coat?

Make a valid sentence from these words
[I] [cannot] [find] [my] [phone]
When I got the invitation I was [excited]
I [have] [been] working on this book [for] two years
My sister has a son and is now [having] another baby.

hint.text: The first letter of the correct answer will be added to each incorrect gap when you press try again.
The next letter of the correct answer will be added when you press try again

questiontext.text:
I like this song. [I will download it.]

I feel very tired. [I think I will go to bed.]

Who were you talking to? [Oh that was my father.]

answer.text: I think I will go to bed.

questiontext.text:
You want to ask a question about the weather and the snow, which is the correct form?

[Is it snowing?]

hint.text: The first letter of the correct answer will be added to each incorrect gap when you press try again.
The next letter of the correct answer will be added when you press try again

questiontext.text: Why did you give John [such] a large serving of rice?
I saw you with him, what did he [say] to you?
Tonight I will stay at home, relax and [watch] TV.

incorrectfeedback.text: If you were to say See TV , or View TV the meaning would be clear but it is not correct English usage

questiontext.text:
The definite article the is the most common determiner used in English.
Drag it into the gap where it is necessary

Can you tell me [the] time?
I don't drink [!!] coffee
My floor is made from [!!] beech wood.
Can you bring [the] phone charger with you?

The definite article the is the most common determiner used in English.

Add it to the gap where necessary

Can you smell something in [the] air?

Can you speak [!!] English?

On the weekend I am going to [!!] London

Can you see [the] sea from your bedroom?

hint.text: The first letter of the correct answer will be added to each incorrect gap when you press try again.
The next letter of the correct answer will be added when you press try again

The next letter of the correct answer will be added when you press try again

The next letter of the correct answer will be added when you press try again

questiontext.text:
Did you remember to buy Milk this morning?

Sorry I forgot, I [will] buy it on the way home.
I [lost] my mobile phone last week, I don't know where it is.
I have been at University [for] three years.  When I finish I [am] going to work as a computer programmer.

[present] I live in Brighton
[past] I was born in York
[present] I am tired

Put this in the simple past tense

When I was a child I [wanted] a bicycle
When talking to his brother my father [spoke] German

hint.text: The first letter of the correct answer will be added to each incorrect gap when you press try again.
The next letter of the correct answer will be added when you press try again

questiontext.text: I [made] more money last year than this year.
I found an interesting article and [cut] it out of the magazine with scissors.
The UK has a wet climate and [it] [often] rains in spring and summer.

incorrectfeedback.text: The verb to walk is a regular verb and so the simple past tense is formed by adding the ed ending , i.e. walked.

questiontext.text: When I was a child I [walked to] school every day.

category.text: $course$/top/Default for qb/Gapfill English Language Questions/Tenses/Present Continuous

questiontext.text: I will stay at home becuse it is [raining].

[I was reading a book when the phone rang]. To begin a story

[He was working hard on learning the piano]. Something happening again and again

[When I got home he was cooking pasta]. Something that happened before and after a particular time

[My English was getting better]. To show change or development

answer.text: I was reading a book when the phone rang
He was working hard on learning the piano
When I got home he was cooking pasta

category.text: $course$/top/Default for qb/Gapfill English Language Questions/Tenses/Past perfect

questiontext.text:
The Past Perfect is made of two parts: the past tense of the verb to have (had) + the past participle of the main verb.

The past perfect is only used when you want to refer to a past that is earlier than another time in the narrative.

Complete this sentences about the past using the right form of the verb in brackets. Use the past perfect tense.
I (see) [saw] him last week, after he  (arrive) [arrived] at the airport.
After I (to leave) [left] work, I (to go) [went] to the park.
By the time I arrived he [had] [gone] out.

category.text: $course$/top/Default for qb/Gapfill English Language Questions/Tenses/Infinitive Past Present

questiontext.text:
Infinitive simple past present perfect
to buy I [bought] I have [bought]
to awake I [awoke] I have [awoken]
to steaI I [stole] I have [stolen]
to shake I [shook] I have [shaken]

hint.text: The first letter of the correct answer will be added to each incorrect gap when you press try again.

The man [who] drove the bus was happy.
There are many schools [that] need new computers.
Jane was on the team [that] won the prize.

incorrectfeedback.text: That is used to refer to things or groups of people, who is used for individuals

questiontext.text: The man [who] delivers the bread is my cousin?

incorrectfeedback.text: The word who is used with a person, the word which is used for anything not human.

category.text: $course$/top/Default for qb/Gapfill English Language Questions/Word Order

questiontext.text:
Put the words into a sentence, taking note of all punctuation.

[Is] [he] [at] [school]?

Create a sentence from these words, takiing account of any punctuation.

[This] [is] [your] [bag]

A participle  is a form of a verb that is used in a sentence to modify a noun, noun phrase, verb, or verb phrase, and plays a role similar to an adjective or adverb.

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Participle

https://en.oxforddictionaries.com/grammar/participles

http://www.englishlanguageguide.com/grammar/participles.asp
